Question.title: Knowledge Check
Question.questionText: It’s only necessary to cite the source of a quotation. In other words, it’s not necessary to cite the source of an idea if you’re paraphrasing it.

answers.feedback: You must include an in-text citation every time you quote or paraphrase another source.
That's correct! You must include an in-text citation every time you quote or paraphrase another source.

Question.title: Knowledge Check
Question.questionText: An in-text citation must include three pieces of information: the name(s) of the author(s), the year the source was published, and the page or paragraph number where the words or idea can be located within that source.

Question.title: Knowledge Check
Question.questionText:
The following is an example of a correctly cited paraphrase, using the "standard citation technique".

When resolving a conflict within a work group, it’s important to allow everyone on the team to voice his or her own opinion on the issue; this will allow for greater clarification of the issue, provide additional reasoning for each argument, and avoid the feeling of preferential treatment amongst the team (Mattson, 2015, para. 7).

Question.title: Knowledge Check
Question.questionText:
The following is an example of a correctly cited quotation, using the "split citation" technique.

According to Mattson (2015), "coworkers may feel the need to agree with each other because they fear losing a friendship" (para. 8)

Question.title: Knowledge Check
Question.questionText: If your paper refers to a particular source more than once, you must list that source the same number of times on your references page.

answers.feedback: You are not correct. The references page lists each source only once.
You are correct! The references page lists each source only once.

Question.title: Knowledge Check
Question.questionText: On the references page, each type of source, e.g., magazine, newspaper, website, is referenced in slightly different ways.
